block.p: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties this week. Items may be submitted by mail, at least three weeks in advance, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, North Salem, N.Y. 10560.
Theater

ELMSFORD -- ''The Sound of Music.'' Opens Thursday with matinee performance at 1 p.m. and lunch at 11:30 a.m. and evening performance at 8, with dinner at 6. Through September. Tickets: $46 to $66, with discounts at selected performances for students, older people and children. Westchester Broadway Theater, 1 Broadway Plaza. (914) 592-2222.

GARRISON -- Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival presents ''Measure for Measure.'' Today at 6 p.m., Wednesday and Thursday at 7 p.m. and next Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $19 to $30, with discounts available (except Saturdays) for students, older people and children. Through July 30. Picnicking encouraged, beginning an hour and a half before shows. Picnic dinners available by reservation. Cost: $16 and $18. Boscobel Restoration, 1601 Route 9D. (845) 265-7858.

NEW ROCHELLE -- ''Comedy at the Club'' with Nikki Carr and other comedians. Presented by Remington Men's Club. Thursday at 8 p.m. Donation: $10. Remington Unit Boys and Girls Club of New Rochelle, 116 Guion Place. (914) 235-0143.

NYACK -- The musical ''Mame,'' starring Carol Lawrence. Tuesday through next Saturday at 8 p.m. and matinee performances today, Wednesday and next Saturday at 2 p.m. Through July 9. Tickets: $25 to $42.50. Helen Hayes Performing Arts Center, 117 Main Street. (914) 358-6333. Music and Dance

DOBBS FERRY -- Flutist, Sherry Winston, and her jazz quartet. Presented as part of Dobbs Ferry summer music series. Wednesday from 6:30 to 8 p.m. Free. Waterfront Park. (Rain location: Embassy Community Center, 60 Palisade Street.) (914) 631-1000.

KATONAH -- Caramoor International Music Festival continuing with Alisa Weilerstein, cellist, and David Lawton, pianist, performing works by Brahms, Dave Heath, Chopin and Rachmaninoff. Thursday at 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $15. Bel Canto at Caramoor presenting ''Whirl of the Dance'' with Laura Danehower Whyte, soprano; Julia Fischer, mezzo-soprano; Francisco Almanza, tenor; Valeriano Lanchas, bass; and Rachelle Jonck and Eric Malson, pianists. Brahms's ''Liebeslieder Walzer'' and other works from Bach to Sondheim. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25. ''Great American Songbook: Sons of a Century'' with Andrea Marcovicci, cabaret artist; Glenn Mehrbach, music director, and Orchestra of St. Luke's. Next Saturday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $75. All-Vivaldi program with Orchestra of St. Luke's. Next Sunday at 4:30 p.m., with preconcert antics (open to ticket holders only) by I Giullari di Piazza, beginning at 1:30. Tickets: $15 to $45. Picnicking encouraged before concert. Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road. (914) 232-1252.

PAWLING -- Invitational open mike finals, with host, Scott Sylvester. Tonight at 7:30. Tickets: $4. Sloan Wainwright Band, with guest artist, Terence Martin. Friday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $17.50; members, $15. Professor Louie and the Crowmatix, featuring Garth Hudson and guest artist, Frank Carillo. Next Saturday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $20; members, $17.50. Towne Crier Cafe, 130 Route 22. (845) 855-1300.

PURCHASE -- Works-in-progress presentation by members of Doug Varone and Dancers. Thursday at 8 p.m. Performance by students of Doug Varone and Dancers workshop. Friday at 8 p.m. Free. Dance theater lab, Conservatory of Dance, Purchase College. (914) 251-6800.
SCARSDALE -- Westchester Band, conducted by Dr. Joseph Albright. Thursday at 8 p.m. Free. Chase Park. (Rain location: Hoff-Barthelson Music School.) (914) 723-7171.

SCARBOROUGH -- Chamber Dance Project's dancers and musicians perform two world premieres and other works, with dancers from American Ballet Theater, Pennsylvania Ballet, Twyla Tharp and Les Grands Ballet Canadiens. Tonight at 7, with cocktails at 6 and dessert and discussion after performance. Tickets: $100 (with $60 tax deductible) to $250 (with $210 tax deductible). Reservations. Sleepy Hollow Country Club. (914) 332-7762.

SOMERS -- Sunset serenade concert by Haitian drum and dance troupe Feel the Beat. Next Saturday at 6 p.m., with gates open for picnicking at 5. Tickets: $10; children 18 and younger, $3. Lasdon Park and Arboretum, Route 35. (914) 693-5595.
YONKERS -- Mount Kisco Scottish Pipes and Drums. Today at noon. Free. Bronx River Parkway Reservation, Scarsdale Road. (914) 242-7275.
Art
DOBBS FERRY -- Exhibition of art by Don Werner and Michael Mancari. Opening reception today, 2 to 5:30 p.m. Through July 30. Main Street Gallery, 26 Main Street. (914) 674-9171.
DOBBS FERRY -- ''Experiments in Sculpture'' by gallery members. Through Friday. Upstream Gallery, 26B Main Street. (914) 674-8548.
ELMSFORD -- Drawings, paintings and collages by Evelyn Klein and her daughter Ellen Cohen. Through Friday. Greenburgh Town Hall. (914) 422-1038.

GARRISON -- ''States Morris Dyckman: The London Purchases,'' exhibition including Wedgwood tea service, Coalport dessert service and Sheffield silver serving platters bought by Mr. Dyckman, a Loyalist during the American Revolution. Daily except Tuesdays from 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., with last tour at 4:15. Admission: $8; people 65 and older, $7; children 6 through 14, $5. Boscobel Restoration, 1601 Route 9D. (845) 265-3638.
HARRISON -- Art by Grace Powers Fraioli. Through Friday. Harrison Public Library, Bruce Avenue. (914) 835-0324.
KATONAH -- Exhibition and sale of photographs about historic Bedford Oak. Through July 19. Candace Perich Gallery, 27 Katonah Avenue. (914) 232-3966.

LARCHMONT -- Photographs of Ireland and Italy by Kevin McDevitt; watercolors by Reiko Oniki and terra cotta and stone sculpture by Judith Litt. Through Wednesday. Larchmont Public Library, 121 Larchmont Avenue. (914) 834-2281.

NORTH SALEM -- Exhibition of 100 vintage advertising posters and other printed matterfrom the 1890's through the Art Deco period. Also works by David Bumbeck and sculpture by Shamus Langlois. Opening reception today from 5 to 7 p.m. Through July 16. Charles Michael Gallery, Routes 116 and 121, Keeler Lane. (914) 669-4600.

PEEKSKILL -- ''Floating Dialogues: Imagery and Abstraction,'' paintings, drawings and printmaking by Dana DeVito, Sergo Gonzalez-Tornero, Tom Halsall, Erik Hanson, William C. Maxwell, Julie Overskei and Tedd Stratis. Through July 29. Paramount Center, 1008 Brown Street. (914) 739-2333.

POCANTICO HILLS -- Guided tours of the church's stained glass windows by Marc Chagall and Henri Matisse. Sundays from 2 to 5 p.m. and Mondays and Wednesdays through Saturdays from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $3. Union Church of Pocantico Hills, 555 Bedford Road, Route 448. (914) 631-2069.

PURCHASE -- Outdoor sculpture by Claes Oldenburg, Louise Nevelson, Alexander Calder, David Wynne and others, set among fountains, flowers and landscaped lawns. Daily from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free. PepsiCo Headquarters, Anderson Hill Road. (914) 253-2000.

PURCHASE -- ''The Group: Women Artists of a New Century,'' constructions by Janet Bohman, sculpture by Marilyn M. Miller, collages by Barbara K. Schwartz and drawings by Susan Sills. Opening reception tomorrow from 5 to 7 p.m. Through July 30. Manhattanville College Library. (914) 323-5277.

PURCHASE -- ''Recent Acquisitions: Selections From the Lawrence Gussman Collection of African Art,'' ''Whitfield Lovell: Portrayals,'' ''Welded! Sculpture of the 20th Century,'' ''Selections From the Roy R. Neuberger Collection,'' ''Object and Intellect: African Art From the Permanent Collection,'' ''Ancient Civilizations: The Roy R. Neuberger Collection'' and (closing next Sunday) ''Carol Hamoy: Portraits of the Artists as Young Girls.'' Tuesdays through Fridays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and Saturdays and Sundays from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; students and people 62 and older, $2. Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase College. (914) 251-6100.

SHRUB OAK -- Paintings by children's book illustrators, Rose Mary Berlin, Jo-Ellen Bosson and Nancy Lane. Opening reception next Saturday from 2 to 4 p.m. Through July 27. John C. Hart Memorial Library, 1130 Main Street. (914) 245-5262.

SOUTH SALEM -- Paintings and sculpture by Vincent Baldassano, Tom Christopher, Mitche Kunzman and others. Sponsored by South Salem Library. Opening reception Friday from 7 to 9 p.m. Through July 21. Onatru Farm, 99 Elmwood Road. (914) 763-3857.

WHITE PLAINS -- ''Westchester in the Movies,'' including photographs from D. W. Griffith's silent films ''Orphans of the Storm'' and ''Way Down East''; scenes from the original 1918 ''Tarzan'' and photographs from recent films with Westchester locations, like ''Age of Innocence'' and ''Ragtime.'' Through Labor Day. Gallery of White Plains Public Library, 100 Martine Avenue. (914) 422-1480.

YONKERS -- ''Fun City: Celebrating the Life of Ralph Fasanella,'' folk artist. Opens Friday. Museum's hours: Wednesdays through Sundays from noon to 5 p.m. and Fridays from 5 to 9 p.m. Admission: $4; people 62 and older and children, $3. Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Avenue. (914) 963-4550.
Films
CHAPPAQUA -- ''The Crowd,'' silent film. Friday at 1:30 and 7:30 p.m. Free. Chappaqua Library, 195 South Greeley Avenue. (914) 238-4779.
PEEKSKILL -- ''The Last September.'' Thursday through next Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $9. Paramount Center, 1008 Brown Street. (914) 739-2333.

SUFFERN -- Independent film series, opening with ''American Movie.'' Presented by Finkelstein Memorial Library. Wednesday at 8 p.m. Donation: $3; students and older people, $1. Rockland Community College. (845) 352-5700, ext. 243.
Lectures

WHITE PLAINS -- Dr. Todd Friend talks about the foods that are most nutritious for older people. Program for people 60 and older also includes ''Vial of Life,'' medical information to be kept in home refrigerators to assist paramedics. Presented by New York United Hospital. Wednesday at 2 p.m. Free. Westchester Medical Group, 210 Westchester Avenue. (914) 934-3668.
YONKERS -- Members of Hudson River Audubon Society and the public show their best nature slides. Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. Free. Lenoir Nature Preserve, 19 Dudley Street. (914) 237-9331.
Children

ARMONK -- Endangered species program, featuring reptiles and small mammals. Presented by Animal Encounters. For children 5 and older. Wednesday at 2 p.m. North Castle Public Library, 19 Whippoorwill Road East. (914) 273-3887.
GREENBURGH -- ''Turtle Trek,'' family groups search the center's grounds for turtle treasures. Today at 2 p.m. Tickets: $8. Greenburgh Nature Center, Dromore Road. (914) 723-3470.

KATONAH -- Group mural workshop for children 9 through 12. Tomorrow through Friday from 1 to 4 p.m. Cost: $65; member's child, $50. Reservations. Katonah Museum of Art, Route 22 at Jay Street. (914) 232-9555.
NEW ROCHELLE -- Ukrainian music and dance. Presented by Ukrainian-American Youth Association. Tuesday from 7:30 to 8:30 p.m. Free. New Rochelle Public Library, Library Lane. (914) 632-7878.

OSSINING -- ''Don't Bug Me!'' Children 8 and 9 scramble on the ground and under rocks and logs in search of invertebrates. Today from 1:30 to 2:30 p.m. Cost: $8; members, $6. Teatown Lake Reservation, 1600 Spring Valley Road. (914) 762-2912.
OSSINING -- ''Magical Time Travel Express,'' reading game kick-off show by Bob Conrad. For school-age children. Tomorrow at 2 p.m. Free. Ossining Public Library, 53 Croton Avenue. (914) 941-2416.

PELHAM -- Ceramics class for children 13 and older and adults. First of six sessions. Tuesday from 7 to 9 p.m. Cost: $120; members, $110. Registration. Pelham Art Center, 155 Fifth Avenue. (914) 738-2525.

RYE -- Summer creative arts program with children in age groups 4 and 5, 6 and 7 and 8 through 10. Classes in drawing, painting, sculpture, drama, storytelling and art of collecting. Tomorrow through Friday from 9:30 a.m. to noon. Cost: $180; members, $162. (Also offered July 5 through 7. Cost: $110; members, $99. July 10 through 14, July 17 through 21, July 24 through 28, July 31 through Aug. 4 and Aug. 7 through 11. Cost: $180 weekly; members, $162.) Registration. Rye Arts Center, 51 Milton Road. (914) 967-0700.

RYE -- Playland Park's summer hours. Sundays (including today) and Tuesdays through Thursdays from noon to 11 p.m. and Fridays and Saturdays from noon to midnight. Also July 3 from noon to midnight. Admission: free. Rides require 3 to 5 tickets each. Cost: 12-ticket book, $8; 24-ticket book, $15; 36-ticket book, $19. Parking: weekdays, $4; weekends, $5; holidays, $7. Exit 19 of New England Thruway. (914) 925-2700.
SOMERS -- ''Udderly in Love with Cows and Ice Cream,'' families learn about cows, make ice cream and visit other farm animals. Today from noon to 3 p.m. Free. Muscoot Farm, Route 100. (914) 232-7118.
WESTCHESTER -- County pools and beaches now open, with twilight-swim program at reduced rate. Daily from 4 p.m. to closing. (914) 242-7275.

WHITE PLAINS -- Bike and skate Sundays, with Bronx River Parkway closed to vehicular traffic and open to bicyclists from the County Center in White Plains to Scarsdale Road in Yonkers, 14 miles round trip. In-line roller skating course runs north from the County Center to Fisher Lane in North White Plains, two miles round trip. Today from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. (Bike and skate Sundays resume Sept. 10.) Free. (914) 242-7275.

YONKERS -- Quilting workshop, with inspiration from Glenview Mansion's tile patterns. Today at 1:30 p.m. Cost: $1 and museum admission additional, $4; people 62 and older and children, $3. Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Avenue. (914) 963-4550.
Potpourri
BEDFORD -- Tree identification hike, looking at leaves, bark and buds for clues. Next Saturday at 2 p.m. Free. Westmoreland Sanctuary, 260 Chestnut Ridge Road. (914) 666-8448.

BREWSTER -- ''Place Matters: A Community Story and History of Southeast, N. Y.,'' exhibition highlighting the relationship between the community and industry of Southeast, from preindustry days to the present. Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and Fridays from noon to 5 p.m. Donation: $3. Southeast Museum, 67 Main Street. (845) 279-7500.

BRONX PARK -- Summer train show, with model engines chugging up rocky, wooded hillsides and winding among flowers and intricately designed replicas of homes of America's storytellers and artists, including Laura Ingalls Wilder's little house on the prairie, Frank Lloyd Wright's Romeo and Juliet windmill and the farmhouse from Grant Wood's ''American Gothic.'' Opens next Saturday at the children's adventure garden. ''Exotic Courtyard Garden,'' lush aquatics and tropical plants displayed in the pools of the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory courtyard. Also opening next Saturday. Bird and butterfly walks. Today from 12:30 to 2 p.m. Bring binoculars. Free with grounds admission: $3; students and older people, $2; children 2 through 12, $1. Free grounds admission all-day on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Children's adventure garden admission: additional $3; students and older people, $2; children, $1. Conservatory admission: $3.50; students and older people, $2.50; children, $2. ''Garden Passport,'' including grounds admission, conservatory, tram tour and children's garden: $10; students and older people, $7.50; children 2 through 12, $4. Garden hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard. (718) 817-8700.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON -- Eighteenth-century dinners served by waiters in period costume with music, wines, ales and cider and 18th-century games brought out with dessert. Saturdays (and July 23) at 5 p.m. Through Aug. 19. Cost: $50; members of Historic Hudson Valley, $45. Van Cortlandt Manor. (914) 631-8200, ext. 618.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON -- ''Taking Care of Business,'' exhibition celebrating Hastings female entrepreneurs who started businesses in the 1970's. Mondays and Thursdays from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Through August. Hastings Historical Society's Observatory Cottage, Draper Park, 407 Broadway.

KATONAH -- Tours of John Jay Homestead. Wednesdays through Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and Sundays from noon to 4 p.m., beginning on the hour. Admission: $3; older people, $2; children, $1. Guided walking tours of the homestead's grounds. Sundays at 2:30 p.m., weather permitting. Free, refreshments included. 400 Jay Street, Route 22. (914) 232-5651.

KATONAH -- ''Queen of Everything: Fabulous Fairy Tales,'' adult storytelling program by Laura Simms. Tuesday at 11 a.m. Tickets: $13, including wine and cheese reception after performance; Friends of Caramoor. $11. Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road. (914) 232-5035, ext. 221.

MOUNT VERNON -- Tour the 225-year-old church bell tower, ascending wooden staircase about 60 feet and having a view of the surrounding area. Tuesday at 3:30 p.m. Cemetery tour focusing on the changing nature of religious symbolism over the centuries, as reflected on the stones. Thursday at 3:30 p.m. Free. St. Paul's Church National Historic Site, 897 South Columbus Avenue. (914) 667-4116.
NEW ROCHELLE -- Exhibition of historic photos of New Rochelle. Opens tomorrow. Through Aug. 4. New Rochelle Public Library, Library Plaza. (914) 632-7878.

NEW ROCHELLE -- First of four sessions in play-reading course. Thursday from 5:30 to 6:45 p.m. Cost: $60, with membership not required. Registration. Jewish Community Center of Mid-Westchester, 999 Wilmot Road. (914) 472-3300, ext. 346.

PELHAM -- Figure-drawing class for adults. First of seven sessions. Thursday from 7 to 9 p.m. Cost: $120; members, $110. Stained glass class. First of six sessions. Friday from 10:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. Cost: $102; $92 for members. Registration. Pelham Art Center, 155 Fifth Avenue. (914) 738-2525.
RYE -- Senior Citizen Outing at Playland. Wednesday from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Playland Park. (914) 241-6352.

SCARSDALE -- ''Real McCoy: Legacy of African-American Innovation,'' exhibition of inventions by African-Americans in the fields of industry, agriculture, transportation and medicine. Wednesdays through Fridays from 1:30 to 4 p.m. and Sundays from 2 to 4 p.m. Through Aug. 20. Admission: $1.50; students and people 65 and older, $1; free admission first Sunday of each month. Scarsdale Historical Society Museum, 937 White Plains Post Road. (914) 723-1744.

SLEEPY HOLLOW -- ''Cross Roads and Cross Rivers: Diversity in Colonial New York,'' exhibition exploring varied cultural expressions made by American Indians, Dutch settlers and African slaves. Daily, except Tuesdays, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Free. Visitors center of Philipsburg Manor, Route 9. (914) 631-8200.
SOMERS -- Workshop on low-maintenance plants. Today from 2 to 3 p.m. Cost: $3. Registration. Lasdon Park and Arboretum, Route 35. (914) 232-9147.
VALHALLA -- African-American heritage celebration. Today from 1 to 7 p.m. Kensico Dam Plaza, north end of Bronx River Parkway. (914) 242-7275.
